main.speaker: Mr. Jefferson
main.text: Very nice, it seems like you would fit in nicely then. Our CEO often walks around on the work floor and is always open for a chat if you want to talk to him.
Oh, that sounds very refreshing. It is a big contrast to the companies where the CEO is some sort of untouchable entity for the regular workforce.

main.speaker: Mr. Jefferson
main.text: Yes, the only form of real hierarchy we have is the relation between product managers and client managers.
What do you mean exactly with that?

main.speaker: Mr. Jefferson
main.text: Basically, we have a client manager who manages the relationship with the client. Each client can have multiple products with us, and that is where the product manager comes in.
Oh, so that means the product managers are below the client managers in a way?

main.speaker: Mr. Jefferson
main.text: Yes, exactly. The client manager is responsible in the end for everything related to that client. On rare occassions, a client manager can also be a product manager for the same client.
But, this does not sound like a very strict hierarchy in the traditional sense, it sounds more like a practical hierarchy.

main.speaker: Mr. Jefferson
main.text: That is what we think too, this was implemented out of necessity and even so, you won't really notice it as much I think.
